headline: Nvidia AI chip sales to China stalled by US security review, FT reports
summary: Nvidia's H200 AI chip sales to China remain in limbo nearly two months after U.S. ​President Donald Trump approved exports, pending a U.S. national ‌security review, the Financial Times reported on Tuesday, citing people familiar with the ‌discussions.  Chinese customers are, meanwhile, not placing H200 chip orders with Nvidia until it becomes clear whether they will be able to secure the licences or what conditions will be attached, the report ⁠said.  Nvidia and the U.S. State Department did not immediately respond to a Reuters ‍request for comment outside regular business hours.

content.title: Nvidia AI chip sales to China stalled by US security review, FT reports
content.summary: Nvidia's H200 AI chip sales to China remain in limbo nearly two months after U.S. ​President Donald Trump approved exports, pending a U.S. national ‌security review, the Financial Times reported on Tuesday, citing people familiar with the ‌discussions.  Chinese customers are, meanwhile, not placing H200 chip orders with Nvidia until it becomes clear whether they will be able to secure the licences or what conditions will be attached, the report ⁠said.  Nvidia and the U.S. State Department did not immediately respond to a Reuters ‍request for comment outside regular business hours.

headline: Nvidia's Huang dismisses fears AI will replace software tools as stock selloff deepens
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang dismissed fears that artificial intelligence will replace software and related tools, calling the ​idea "illogical", after a significant selloff in global software stocks on ‌Tuesday.  The selloff, partly sparked by AI developer Anthropic's updated chatbot release last week that ‌heightened fears of AI-driven disruption in the data and professional services industry, broadened on Wednesday, hitting software stocks in India, Japan and China.  Speaking at an artificial intelligence conference in San Francisco hosted by Cisco Systems ⁠Huang said worries that AI ‌will make software companies less relevant are misguided and AI will continue to rely on existing software rather ‍than rebuild basic tools from scratch.

content.title: Nvidia's Huang dismisses fears AI will replace software tools as stock selloff deepens
content.summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang dismissed fears that artificial intelligence will replace software and related tools, calling the ​idea "illogical", after a significant selloff in global software stocks on ‌Tuesday.  The selloff, partly sparked by AI developer Anthropic's updated chatbot release last week that ‌heightened fears of AI-driven disruption in the data and professional services industry, broadened on Wednesday, hitting software stocks in India, Japan and China.  Speaking at an artificial intelligence conference in San Francisco hosted by Cisco Systems ⁠Huang said worries that AI ‌will make software companies less relevant are misguided and AI will continue to rely on existing software rather ‍than rebuild basic tools from scratch.

thumbnail.caption: FILE PHOTO: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang in Las Vegas

headline: Anthropic's new AI tools deepen selloff in data analytics and software stocks, investors say
summary: A significant selloff among U.S. and European data analytics, professional services and software companies deepened on Tuesday, with some investors pointing to a recently updated artificial intelligence chatbot by Anthropic as ​the main culprit.  AI developer Anthropic launched plug-ins for its Claude Cowork agent on Friday that would automate tasks across legal, sales, marketing and ‌data analysis.  Toronto-based Thomson Reuters, which owns the Westlaw legal database, slumped by nearly 18%.

content.title: Anthropic's new AI tools deepen selloff in data analytics and software stocks, investors say
content.summary: A significant selloff among U.S. and European data analytics, professional services and software companies deepened on Tuesday, with some investors pointing to a recently updated artificial intelligence chatbot by Anthropic as ​the main culprit.  AI developer Anthropic launched plug-ins for its Claude Cowork agent on Friday that would automate tasks across legal, sales, marketing and ‌data analysis.  Toronto-based Thomson Reuters, which owns the Westlaw legal database, slumped by nearly 18%.

headline: AMD's Frankfurt-listed shares fall after weaker sales
summary: Advanced Micro Devices ​shares fell ‌over 6% in ‌early Frankfurt trading on Wednesday after the ⁠company ‌forecast a slight decline in ‍quarterly revenue, raising concerns about whether ​it can ‌effectively challenge Nvidia in the booming AI market. The stock ended ⁠Tuesday's regular ​session ​down 1.7%. The shares have ‍risen ⁠13.1% so far this year (Reporting ⁠by Danilo Masoni; ‌Editing by Amanda ‌Cooper)

headline: AI Weekly: OpenAI Nvidia tensions? Wild week for AI stocks
summary:
STORY: From possible tensions between OpenAI and Nvidia to a wild week for AI-related stocks, this is AI Weekly.

:: AI Weekly

OpenAI isn't happy with some of Nvidia's latest AI chips.

That was the words from sources, who said Sam Altman's firm has sought alternatives since last year.

They said the ChatGPT-maker isn't satisfied with the speed at which Nvidia's hardware can give answers to specific issues like software development.

Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang had earlier said reports of tension between the two was - quote - 'nonsense'.

Meanwhile, the Financial Times reported Nvidia's H200 AI chip sales to China are still uncertain due to a U.S. national security review.

It said the U.S. State Department wants tougher restrictions.

It aims to make it harder for China to use the H200 chips in ways that would undermine U.S. national security.

The report added Chinese customers haven't placed orders until it's clear they can secure licenses and know what conditions will be attached.

AI-related stocks went through a wild week.

Tech majors like Meta, ASML and SK Hynix soared. 

Investors bought the Facebook-parent as it boosted spending plans by close to three quarters in pursuit of "superintelligence".

That's where machines surpass human performance.

But other major tech stocks like Microsoft and AMD struggled.

Microsoft endured a more than 10% one day drop after AI spending worried investors.

The firm only edged past forecasts for quarterly revenue on its cloud-computing business, and ramped up AI spending.

That disappointed market watchers who wanted better returns amid intense competition.

And Samsung forecast chip shortages will get worse this year due to the AI boom.

It expects any expansion of memory chip supply to be limited over the next two years while AI-related demand stays strong.

However, revenues were up big time in the fourth quarter for the world's top memory chipmaker.

Operating profit at Samsung's chip business surged 470% to a record high $11.4 billion in the fourth quarter from a year earlier.

content.title: AI Weekly: OpenAI Nvidia tensions? Wild week for AI stocks
content.summary:
STORY: From possible tensions between OpenAI and Nvidia to a wild week for AI-related stocks, this is AI Weekly.

:: AI Weekly

OpenAI isn't happy with some of Nvidia's latest AI chips.

That was the words from sources, who said Sam Altman's firm has sought alternatives since last year.

They said the ChatGPT-maker isn't satisfied with the speed at which Nvidia's hardware can give answers to specific issues like software development.

Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang had earlier said reports of tension between the two was - quote - 'nonsense'.

Meanwhile, the Financial Times reported Nvidia's H200 AI chip sales to China are still uncertain due to a U.S. national security review.

It said the U.S. State Department wants tougher restrictions.

It aims to make it harder for China to use the H200 chips in ways that would undermine U.S. national security.

The report added Chinese customers haven't placed orders until it's clear they can secure licenses and know what conditions will be attached.

AI-related stocks went through a wild week.

Tech majors like Meta, ASML and SK Hynix soared. 

Investors bought the Facebook-parent as it boosted spending plans by close to three quarters in pursuit of "superintelligence".

That's where machines surpass human performance.

But other major tech stocks like Microsoft and AMD struggled.

Microsoft endured a more than 10% one day drop after AI spending worried investors.

The firm only edged past forecasts for quarterly revenue on its cloud-computing business, and ramped up AI spending.

That disappointed market watchers who wanted better returns amid intense competition.

And Samsung forecast chip shortages will get worse this year due to the AI boom.

It expects any expansion of memory chip supply to be limited over the next two years while AI-related demand stays strong.

However, revenues were up big time in the fourth quarter for the world's top memory chipmaker.

Operating profit at Samsung's chip business surged 470% to a record high $11.4 billion in the fourth quarter from a year earlier.

headline: Nvidia's China chip sales stalled by US security review: FT
summary:
STORY: Nvidia’s H200 AI chip sales to China are in question due to a pending U.S. national security review. 

That’s according to the Financial Times Tuesday (February 3), citing sources. 

It comes almost two months after U.S. President Donald Trump approved the tech giant’s exports. 

Meanwhile, the report said, Chinese customers aren't placing orders for the powerful H200 chip with Nvidia. 

They’re waiting for clarity on whether they’ll be able to secure licenses - or the conditions that could be attached. 

Reuters couldn't immediately verify the report. 

Nvidia and the U.S. State Department didn't immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment.

In January, the Commerce Department eased export curbs on the H200 for China.

But it required license applications to be reviewed by the U.S. departments of State, Defense and Energy.

According to the FT, the Commerce Department has completed its analysis but the State Department was pushing for tougher restrictions...

With its goal being to make it harder for China to use the H200 chips in ways that would undermine U.S. national security.

Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang said last week his firm's license to sell the chip in the country is being finalized.

Reuters reported last month that China had approved its first batch of H200 chips for import.

It marks a shift for Beijing as it tries to balance its AI needs against pushing domestic development.

content.title: Nvidia's China chip sales stalled by US security review: FT
content.summary:
STORY: Nvidia’s H200 AI chip sales to China are in question due to a pending U.S. national security review. 

That’s according to the Financial Times Tuesday (February 3), citing sources. 

It comes almost two months after U.S. President Donald Trump approved the tech giant’s exports. 

Meanwhile, the report said, Chinese customers aren't placing orders for the powerful H200 chip with Nvidia. 

They’re waiting for clarity on whether they’ll be able to secure licenses - or the conditions that could be attached. 

Reuters couldn't immediately verify the report. 

Nvidia and the U.S. State Department didn't immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment.

In January, the Commerce Department eased export curbs on the H200 for China.

But it required license applications to be reviewed by the U.S. departments of State, Defense and Energy.

According to the FT, the Commerce Department has completed its analysis but the State Department was pushing for tougher restrictions...

With its goal being to make it harder for China to use the H200 chips in ways that would undermine U.S. national security.

Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang said last week his firm's license to sell the chip in the country is being finalized.

Reuters reported last month that China had approved its first batch of H200 chips for import.

It marks a shift for Beijing as it tries to balance its AI needs against pushing domestic development.

headline: AMD falls as dour forecast shows cracks in AI trade
summary: Advanced Micro Devices shares fell nearly 7% in premarket trading on Wednesday after the chipmaker's lackluster quarterly sales forecast rekindled investor doubts over its ability ​to take on AI chip bellwether Nvidia. The chipmaker's retreat comes alongside a broader selloff ‌in global software stocks tied to fears that AI will replace software and related tools, following an updated chatbot release from ‌AI developer Anthropic. For hardware makers such as Nvidia and AMD, the risk remains that AI tools have shown limited real-world productivity gains and investor patience with Big Tech's mounting AI spending is waning.

content.title: AMD falls as dour forecast shows cracks in AI trade
content.summary: Advanced Micro Devices shares fell nearly 7% in premarket trading on Wednesday after the chipmaker's lackluster quarterly sales forecast rekindled investor doubts over its ability ​to take on AI chip bellwether Nvidia. The chipmaker's retreat comes alongside a broader selloff ‌in global software stocks tied to fears that AI will replace software and related tools, following an updated chatbot release from ‌AI developer Anthropic. For hardware makers such as Nvidia and AMD, the risk remains that AI tools have shown limited real-world productivity gains and investor patience with Big Tech's mounting AI spending is waning.

headline: Global software stocks hit by Anthropic wake-up call on AI disruption
summary: European and U.S. software stocks struggled to find support on Wednesday as a sector-wide selloff spread to Asia, fuelled by mounting worries that advances in artificial intelligence could upend companies' business ​models.  European data analytics, professional services and software stocks fell for a second day in volatile trade, mirroring losses in ‌global peers, after Anthropic's new legal artificial intelligence model underscored the threat to businesses seen as most exposed to AI disruption.  Shares of U.S. software and services firms were mixed in premarket trading after a near 13% slide over five straight sessions.

content.title: Global software stocks hit by Anthropic wake-up call on AI disruption
content.summary: European and U.S. software stocks struggled to find support on Wednesday as a sector-wide selloff spread to Asia, fuelled by mounting worries that advances in artificial intelligence could upend companies' business ​models.  European data analytics, professional services and software stocks fell for a second day in volatile trade, mirroring losses in ‌global peers, after Anthropic's new legal artificial intelligence model underscored the threat to businesses seen as most exposed to AI disruption.  Shares of U.S. software and services firms were mixed in premarket trading after a near 13% slide over five straight sessions.

headline: Texas Instruments to buy chip designer Silicon Labs in $7.5 billion deal
summary: Texas Instruments on Wednesday agreed to buy Silicon Laboratories in a deal valuing the ​chip designer at $7.5 billion, expanding its footprint in ‌wireless connectivity chips used for industrial and consumer applications.  For Texas, whose core ‌strength lies in analog chips that manage signals and power in electronic equipment, the acquisition marks its biggest since the $6.5 billion deal for National Semiconductor in 2011.

content.title: Texas Instruments to buy chip designer Silicon Labs in $7.5 billion deal
content.summary: Texas Instruments on Wednesday agreed to buy Silicon Laboratories in a deal valuing the ​chip designer at $7.5 billion, expanding its footprint in ‌wireless connectivity chips used for industrial and consumer applications. headline: Nvidia's Huang Says It's 'Illogical' to Think AI Will Replace Software Tools
summary: Worries about artificial intelligence disrupting the software business are overblown, Nvidia Chief Executive Jensen Huang said.  "There's this notion that the software industry is in decline and will be replaced by AI," Huang said late Tuesday at an event hosted by Cisco, hours after a selloff in U.S. software stocks.  "There's a whole bunch of software companies whose stock prices are under a lot of pressure because somehow AI is going to replace them," Huang said.

content.title: Nvidia's Huang Says It's 'Illogical' to Think AI Will Replace Software Tools
content.summary: Worries about artificial intelligence disrupting the software business are overblown, Nvidia Chief Executive Jensen Huang said.  "There's this notion that the software industry is in decline and will be replaced by AI," Huang said late Tuesday at an event hosted by Cisco, hours after a selloff in U.S. software stocks.  "There's a whole bunch of software companies whose stock prices are under a lot of pressure because somehow AI is going to replace them," Huang said.

headline: AMD Struggles to Bridge the Gap Between AI Hope and Near-Term Reality
summary: AMD  is finding out how tough it can be when you’re riding high in the artificial-intelligence investment trade.  The stock had been one of the market’s top performers over the past six months, outpacing its larger rival,  Nvidia  by nearly 36% in terms of overall gains.  It also was up more than 40% from its early October close heading into the release Tuesday of fourth-quarter earnings, powered in part by a multi-billion dollar deal with OpenAI to deploy its next-generation GPUs in exchange for warrants that could see the ChatGPT maker owning as much as 10% of AMD outstanding stock.

content.title: AMD Struggles to Bridge the Gap Between AI Hope and Near-Term Reality

The stock had been one of the market’s top performers over the past six months, outpacing its larger rival,  Nvidia  by nearly 36% in terms of overall gains.  It also was up more than 40% from its early October close heading into the release Tuesday of fourth-quarter earnings, powered in part by a multi-billion dollar deal with OpenAI to deploy its next-generation GPUs in exchange for warrants that could see the ChatGPT maker owning as much as 10% of AMD outstanding stock.

headline: AMD falls as dour forecast shows tough competition in AI trade
summary: Advanced Micro Devices shares sank 13% on Wednesday after the company's lackluster sales forecast deepened investor doubts about its ability to take on AI chip ​bellwether Nvidia.  AMD predicted its revenue would fall slightly in the current quarter, even as ‌a resumption of China sales gives an unexpected boost, showing its struggle to penetrate the booming market where Nvidia is ‌aggressively defending its position.

headline: Texas Instruments strikes $7.5 billion deal for Silicon Labs to boost wireless footprint
summary: Texas Instruments on Wednesday agreed to buy chip designer Silicon Laboratories for about $7.5 billion, aiming to ​expand its presence in wireless connectivity chips used in industrial and ‌consumer applications.  For TI, whose core strength lies in analog chips that manage signals and power ‌in electronic equipment, the acquisition marks its biggest since the $6.5 billion deal for National Semiconductor in 2011.  Unlike AI chip firms Nvidia and AMD, TI focuses on foundational chips used in everyday devices such as smartphones, cars and medical devices, giving ⁠it a large client ‌base that includes Apple, SpaceX and Ford.

content.title: Texas Instruments strikes $7.5 billion deal for Silicon Labs to boost wireless footprint
content.summary: Texas Instruments on Wednesday agreed to buy chip designer Silicon Laboratories for about $7.5 billion, aiming to ​expand its presence in wireless connectivity chips used in industrial and ‌consumer applications.  For TI, whose core strength lies in analog chips that manage signals and power ‌in electronic equipment, the acquisition marks its biggest since the $6.5 billion deal for National Semiconductor in 2011.  Unlike AI chip firms Nvidia and AMD, TI focuses on foundational chips used in everyday devices such as smartphones, cars and medical devices, giving ⁠it a large client ‌base that includes Apple, SpaceX and Ford.

headline: Nvidia-rival Cerebras Systems valued at $23.1 billion in latest financing
summary: AI chipmaker Cerebras Systems said on Wednesday it raised $1 billion in a late-stage funding round that valued it ​at $23 billion, nearly tripling its valuation just over four months after ‌its previous financing.  The round was led by Tiger Global.  AI-linked companies have continued to draw billions in private financing as corporations and governments race to develop data centers for supporting the still-nascent technology.
